title: Are you from a country that no one knows even exists? - Quora

response.answer_text: The country that I am from is a tiny country in East Africa that just gained independence and became an official nation in 1993.  The country is called Eritrea, and every single person I’ve mentioned it to that lives in the U.S. has never heard of. In the early 1900’s, it was colonized by European powers such as England and Italy, and then was annexed to Ethiopia after World War 2. Eventually, the Eritrean People’s Liberation Front revolted against the Ethiopian government and a bloody and long war began, and Eritreans gained our independence. Eritrea has a population of 4.79 million, and the most commonly spoken language is Tigrinya, although Amharic (the Ethiopian language) is also spoken frequently. The country is about 50% Orthodox Christian and 50% Muslim. The capital city is Asmara, which is a beautiful town with Italian style architechure.    The rural regions are desertlike and mountainous. The poverty level is high in these areas.   The Massawa beach borders the Red Sea, and is the premiere vacation destination for Eritreans. I could see it becoming a more popular area worldwide if it wasn’t so difficult to reach.  If you’re familiar with the culture of Ethiopia, the culture of Eritrea is very similar. The traditional clothing is white robes with a jeweled color pattern for men and women, although sometimes, especially in Asmara, more Western clothes are worn.   The most common dish eaten is injera, a type of spongy flat bread, and it is served with lots of meat and veggies. Honestly, it’s delicious, and if you’re ever near an Ethiopian/Eritrean restaurant (there are lots in bigger cities) I would highly reccomend visiting. It’s a new experience, as you eat with your hands and share a large dish with other people.  Interested in visiting now? Unfortunately, the country is practically impossible for people without an Eritrean ID to get into. This is due to the dictatorlike “government” currently in place, which has caused Eritrea to be one of the worst countries in terms of human rights issues. It is 2nd in number to only Syria in number of refugees coming into Europe, and it is ranked last in the world, below North Korea, for freedom of the press. It’s one of the most oppressed countries that no one knows about. Hopefully I taught you something about a pretty small, overlooked country. I love it and it’s my heritage, and I hope that one day it can become a peaceful and stable country that tourists will flock to, because it is truly rich in culture and beauty.

I’ve written a similar post to this, so if you are rereading this, beg my pardon! I’m from a country called Kazakhstan, and trust me, it is neither small nor an island. Actually, we don’t even have an access to the ocean or sea. Oh also, it is not even a small country. Kazakhstan is the ninth largest country on our planet, landlocked largest.  What? Kazaakistan? Wait, what? Where is it? [Sometimes, people cannot even pronounce it] You might actually ask me why I’m even mentioning Kazakhstan? Well, it started when I was teaching elementary school math as a volunteer in South Africa. Teachers asked where I am from, and I said, Kazakhstan. Their immediate reaction was whether I eat dogs or not. My first reaction to this was: “No, I don’t. But I eat horse meat”. (Oh boy, you have to see their face: from dogs to horses). This is their way of dealing with a person from an unknown country. Second time, it happened when I visited New Orleans two years ago. We were boat-touring in local swamps and the tour-guide started asking us where we (tourists) are from. Everybody started saying Nebraska, Canada, Germany, etc. My best friend from Kazakhstan said she is from Kazakhstan and everybody stared at her, and the tour guide asked her two more times. So, basically, when I got my turn, I just said Russia (sorry, Russian readers). No further questions. I’m question-free and I don’t have to repeat Kazakhstan three times. (I agree, not my proudest moment!) Now, I’m living in the Bay Area, the most educated part of the United States. When I say, I’m from Kazakhstan, people give you nice surprise look and tell me, ‘oh you are the first person I’ve met from Kazakhstan’. Then, it’s over. People don’t know anything about that part of the world. And of course, I’m a weirdo, I bring up Borat. So far from my experience, almost everybody has watched that movie. Since people here are politically correct, they never ask about Borat first. So I have to bring it up. It is a funny interaction. And last, I know geography very well (I even know the capitals of 50 states, my friends will confirm this). For me, an unknown country is Papua New Guinea. I mean I know the country, where it is located. However, I would love to visit this country! The link to my post about Kazakhstan.

For the longest time I had no idea that I was actually from the Republic of Udostan, a small country which got its independence from Greater Udonia in 2020 BCE. Now, one would think it impossible to come from a country that no one knows even exists. None of the other 100+ answerers to this question have answered it correctly. Somebody somewhere knows each and every one of their countries exist. Not mine. No one knows the Republic of Udostan even exists. (Hence this being the only accurate answer to this question.)I don’t even know that the Republic of Udostan exists. Its existence cannot be verified by our government or any other country’s investigative agencies. Much like the God of all revealed religions, its existence must be taken on faith. My father and mother and their fathers and mothers and all fathers and mothers in my ancestry were told of the Republic of Udostan and believed in its existence purely on faith alone. Yet they could not know. Could never know. So it lives on in myth. All the accounts of its glorious history, the world changing events brought about by its citizens, enlightened as to their true iguana natures, preserved in the great Chronicles of Udonia, and later in the Gospels of Udostan, have been closely guarded and secreted away from the eyes of a prying world. Being mythology, they contain no knowledge per se, only instructions to have faith in the sacred scrolls. One can only be ‘from’ the Republic of Udostan, and not reside within it because…it does not exist. Duh! Fallacies still abound even up to the present day. For example, Quora Moderation has accepted the existence of the Republic of Udostan….purely on faith. Proof can be found in the comment section of this obscure answer: Dane Clarke's answer to I have often read that the thundering herds of ululating lizards in the Republic of Udostan are breath taking and unequaled anywhere else in the world. Can this be verified or is it simply marketing hype? in Down the Rabbit Hole And the rumors and gossip about the Republic of Udostan persist as well. (Promulgated mainly by this nefarious individual) Udo Andre's answer to I have often read that the thundering herds of ululating lizards in the Republic of Udostan are breath taking and unequaled anywhere else in the world. Can this be verified or is it simply marketing hype? in Down the Rabbit Hole So persistent are the stories like those above, that it has been taken for granted and believed by those at the bottom of the world. Thought to be common knowledge. Yet believed on faith alone. We can be thankful there has been no religious fanaticism. Udostanism could very well have replaced the world’s religions. And then where would we be?  [More can be learned here:] Jeffrey Ferreri's post: Lizard based communication takes a giant leap forward. [Bonus feature:] National anthem of the Republic of Udostan: uuuudo udo udo uuduuduududododadadadlalalalalalalalalalalalalalala !!!

I might say it’s the Philippines though.  For all the fame-oriented mentality of my countrymen, most of them will get happily triggered and shout the proverbial “Pinoy Pride” the moment a famous American or Western celebrity ever dare mention the name of my country. That alone may prove that most of the world do not know there was a nation called the Philippines existing in this world. Even the recent times’ Duterte’s cursing-based fame or Manny Pacquiao’s fast-moving boxing skills didn’t do that much to hit my country into the international spotlight. (Disclaimer: I bet you don’t even know Manny lmao)  This is Manny Pacquiao btw. Now you guys know him. He used to be an 8-time world boxing champ and a national pride for every Filipino. Now he’s a senator in our country. I might not say that Philippines is a country which no one knows even exists, given now that Russia, China, the rest of East Asia, the USA, and the Middle East very well know our presence (thanks to our overseas workers, diaspora worldwide and Duterte’s diplomacy), but the fact that it is not-so-highlighted in the international media (being highlighted less than Burma, Thailand, Indonesia or Vietnam) and with the absolute majority of this world not knowing our country’s existence, I’d say that my statement was somehow affirmed. Not to mention… My country was the first to fight the United States during the eve and dawn of the 20th century in a failing fight for independence; in fact, that was the USA’s first real war in Asia No one in the world except some of our neighbors know that my country was one of the two in East Asia having a Christian majority (the other being East Timor, also a far less known country), coming from a national population of more than a hundred million people. My country is the only Asian country in the world whose people, or at least most of them, has Hispanic names and surnames. Pay attention to my name and that’s a proof. Isn’t that weird?Most of my countrymen with my notable exception is taking the lead in favoring the United States worldwide. You may know more about the Philippines either because of my answer or the moment President Duterte spews off some international cussing again, but until then, the world’s majority will never know that there is such a country.

I’m from Montenegro. Things people say after: Person 1: Negro? But…but…that’s racist! Me: No, it means black. Like the colour black *sigh* Person 2: Are you sure it’s in Europe? Me: Unless we skipped continents in the meantime, it was still there last time I checked. Person 3: So is that in Russia? Me: No, it’s a separate country. It’s pretty far from Russia. Some 2000ish km, but who’s counting. Person 4: Oh, I know, Yugoslavia! Me: Not anymore, that ended some 20 years ago. Person 5: Oh, like Serbia & Montenegro Me: Not anymore, that ended about 13 years ago. Aaaaaaaaanyway, back on track:  The flag. Welcome, ladies and gentlemen, or as we say Dobro došli, dame i gospodo! Montenegro is a small Balkan country with rugged mountains, medieval villages and a narrow strip of beaches along its Adriatic coastline. On the map of Europe we’re that small red dot.  It’s really a tiny country. Its total size is 13,812 km2 (5,333 sq mi), 156th in the world. Its population is also small, only 660,879 people. There are cities in the world with larger suburbs. Capital: Podgorica  Official languages: Montenegrin (national) Serbian, Bosnian, Albanian, Croatian (in official use (don’t bite my head off nationals, just copying from wikipedia) Writing systems: Cyrillic and Latin. Like Serbia, Montenegro uses both, and both of them are official. Ethnic groups: (see languages) 47.5% Montenegrins 27.7% Serbs 7.6% Bosniaks 3.9% Albanians 0.9% Croats 13.6% Others Religion: 75.93% Christianity (Eastern Orthodoxy is the majorty, about 70%, while Catholicism is about 3%) 19.21% Islam 3.31% Irreligious 3.65% Others Now, enough about the boring stuff. Let’s get down to business (to defeat the Huns…just kidding). The country got its name (literally, “black mountain”) from the dark, mountain forests that cover the land. The original name is Crna Gora. Some 60% of the country is more than 1,000 meters (3,280 feet) high. Yup, we’re very mountainous! Bobotov Kuk is a peak in northern Montenegro. At 2,523 meters (8,278 feet), it is the highest peak in the Durmitor mountain range and the highest point in Montenegro. The picture below is of Bobotov Kuk.  Montenegro has five national parks which cover approximately 10 percent of the country’s territory. They are: NP Durmitor, NP Lovćen, NP Biogradska gora, NP Skadarsko jezero, NP Prokletije. The Durmitor National Park, created in 1952, includes the massif of Durmitor, the canyons of Tara, Sušica and Draga rivers and the higher part of the canyon plateau Komarnica, covering the area of 390 km² (150 square miles).It was inscribed on the list of UNESCO World Heritage Sites in 1980. Montenegro may be small but it is the home of 3 UNESCO World Heritage Sites (we’ll get to them in a minute).  The Durmitor National park and the Black Lake (Crno jezero). The Tara River Canyon also known as the Tara River Gorge, is the longest canyon in Montenegro. It is 82 kilometers (51 miles) long and is 1,300 meters (4,300 feet) at its deepest, making it the deepest river canyon in Europe.  Lake Skadar - also called Lake Scutari, Lake Shkodër and Lake Shkodra lies on the border of Albania and Montenegro, the largest lake in the Balkan Peninsula.  Biogradska Gora is a forest and a national park in Montenegro within Kolašin municipality. It is the site of one of the last three rainforests in Europe.  Lovćen is a mountain and national park in southwestern Montenegro.Mount Lovćen rises from the borders of the Adriatic basin, closing the long and twisting bays of Boka Kotorska and making the hinterland to the coastal town of Kotor. Besides Lovćen’s natural beauties, the rich historical, cultural and architectural heritage of the area are protected by the national park. The biggest and most important monument of Lovćen national park is Petar Petrović Njegoš’s Mausoleum. The Mausoleum is very impressive as well.  And the inside is quite badass.  The Natural and Culturo-Historical Region of Kotor is a UNESCO World Heritage Site located in Montenegro that was inscribed in 1979. It encompasses the old town of Kotor, the fortifications of Kotor, and the surrounding region of the inner Bay of Kotor. Also my hometown, so I get bragging rights.  Since we are here, let’s visit Perast, one of the most beautiful little places in Boka Bay, few kilometers from Kotor.  Don’t know why Perast got the sunny weather, but Kotor got the gloomy dark clouds, but don’t worry. It doesn’t rain that often in Kotor (at least not during the summer). The summers get quite hot, about 35°C+ usually. So if you’re coming by during the summer, bring your bikini and sunscreen!. Speaking of rain, though, a nearby place called Crkvice was for a while the place with the highest annual rainfall in Europe (I think a place in Norway beat us at rain). The Monastery of Ostrog is a monastery of the Serbian Orthodox Church sitatued against an almost vertical background, high up in the large rock of Ostroška Greda, in Montenegro.Ostrog monastery is the most popular pilgrimage place in Montenegro. Unless you’re specifically coming to visit, I’d avoid it during the 11th, 12th, and 13th of May. 12th of May is St. Vasilije Day, so a lot (and I mean A LOT) of people go there. People camp out, and carry his icon and walk through Nikšić (a town nearby). But the place is beautiful, and quite surreal to visit because it is literraly carved into the mountain. The Monastery is known for its healing factors. There are a lot of miracles coming from this place.  The Montenegrin Adriatic coast is 295 kilometers (183. miles) long, with 72 kilometers (45 miles) of beaches. Montenegro has a total of 117 beaches. The Big Beach (Velika Plaza) in Ulcinj is 13 kilometers (8 miles) long and 60 meters (197 feet) wide.  One of the most iconic images associated with Montenegro is the tiny islet of Sveti Stefan. There is a church on the hill above, where Novak Đoković got married (the #1 tennis player from Serbia, if you’ve lived under a rock).  Husein-Paša’s Mosque in Pljevlja. It is regarded as "one of the most beautiful sacral monuments of Islamic architecture in Montenegro".  Stecci Medieval Tombstone Graveyard refers to the medieval tombstones covering 28 sites that are found across Bosnia and Herzegovina, and in western parts of Montenegro, and southern and central part Croatia. These graveyards date back to the period between 12th and 16th centuries, and they are laid in rows because that was the traditional custom in the medieval Europe and during the middle ages. Stecci was inscribed by UNESCO as a cultural world heritage site in 2016.  The Nevidio Canyon is one of the last discovered canyons in Europe (it was finally conquered in 1965). Its name literally means “unseen” because of the inaccessible terrain. It is located in the North of Montenegro. If you’re an adventure seaker, this is a good place for you, but be warned, it’s pretty hard to cross it. Mix consists of climbing, adrenalin, jumping into the turbulent waves from several meters in height, adrenalin, swimming through cuts, diving, descending down the cliffs and waterfalls, with or without ropes... and did I mention adrenalin?  Some other random facts: In the teritory of today’s Montenegro (Obod) in 1493 was printed the first Cyrillic book in the Slavic South, Oktoih Prvoglasnik. The most famous Montenegrin export products are wine ”Vranac “and smoked ham (njeguški pršut).  Damn that is good. And salty, but hella good. If you want to party and enjoy the view, I recommend Budva. It’s a cool place to enjoy during the day, and have fun at night.  During the summer, because we are a tourist spot, there are many festivals. Among the famous are: Carnival and Bokeška noć in Kotor, Festival of Wine and Fish in Petrovac (close to Budva), and many newer things. Hollywood star Brad Pitt played his first role in a movie “Dark side of the Sun” which was recorded in Montenegrin Coast in 1987. Montenegrin director Božidar- Bota Nikolić chose Pit for this role. Brad was especially amazed by the beauty of Perast. Part of the 2006 James Bond film Casino Royale is set in Montenegro, although all of the filming was done in the Czech Republic – Karlovy Vary. Nice try, Martin Campbell, we all saw through you. Thanks for getting my hopes up for nothing. And there you have it. I’ve only scratched the surface of the beauty of my country, and there is of course so so many more beautiful (and fun!) things and places to see and do here. So if you’re wondering if you should come and visit, yes, you should. Thank you! ~ Edit: Just corrected some info about the Big beach in Ulcinj, and added a picture. Thanks for the views, upvotes, and comments! Edit 2: Some minor corrections. Again, thank you for the views, upvotes, and kind comments! To all of those who have already visited my country, I hope you’ve had a lovely time, and come back soon!

I am!This is Cyprus  Cyprus is an island-country in the Mediterranean sea, we’re southeast of Greece and south of Turkey. We also have a pretty…complicated history. We were hellenized in ancient times and kept our Greek identity throughout the many years we were conquered.We gained our independence from the British in 1960, but in the midst of political chaos, we were invaded in 1974 by Turkey and now we are a divided nation. In the South is the Republic of Cyprus and in the North the Turkish Republic of Northen Cyprus (which is a self-declared state). I’m from the Southern part so that’s all I can tell you about. When I told my internet friends where I’m from, they had no idea what Cyprus was, so I’d say we’re pretty unknown to the world. Even so, our beaches attract a lot of tourists, they’re beautiful.  We joined the EU in 2004 and entered the Eurozone in 2008. Nicosia is the capital and it’s actually the only divided capital in the EU. The city is surrounded by the Venetian Walls, built by the Republic of Venice in the 16th century.   Our official languages are Greek and Turkish and we celebrate our independence day on October 1st. Also, here’s a fun fact, every morning on July 20th at exactly 5:30 am air raid sirens are sounded throughout the country in memory of the invasion. It also happens on July 15th at 8:20 am as a reminder of the military coup against the President, which also happened in 1974.Here are some more pictures!  The Larnaca international airport  The baths of Aphrodite  Lania village As for the people here, well, most hold “traditional” views so the island needs to go a long way to let go of old prejudices. They also value learning a lot, everyone sends their kid to university and academic prowess is very important. History is something that people value too, they’re very proud of their roots. Even so, we’re generally known as pretty friendly! Things are currently changing, people are pushing for new ideas and there is a possibility of a re-unification of the island, which would make things very different.To be honest, it can be suffocating to live on a small island with little opportunities, where many things seem to be stuck in the past, but hey, it’s where I ended up being born and there’s good things about it too I can appreciate. Hope I gave a good answer!

so… when you hear about Africa, what’s the first country that comes to mind? a. Nigeria? b. South Africa c. Uganda d. Ghana I’m pretty sure nobody had heard of this country. Well… unless you live in a French-speaking country or you ACTUALLY live near the country. When I was younger, I used to be very insecure with my country that I wouldn’t tell anyone about it. The fact that it doesn’t have any landmarks made me feel uncomfortable to talk about it. Visiting the country didn’t make a difference. Their culture is too strict that as a trans male I never wanted to go there again, even when that one time I went was for school. I found their culture a bit annoying. They’re obsessed with their religion that they would SCREAM AT THE MIDDLE OF THE NIGHT WHILST I’M TRYING TO GET MY BEAUTY SLEEP! I have no problem with other people’s beliefs but they can force it a bit on people and that’s very annoying. As an athiest trans male, I didn’t have the best experience there. It might be mainly because I was transgender and that kinda ruined the experience for me as when my big sister was young, she had an amazing time in that country. The difference was she was a cisgender female and I was a transgender male. Or maybe it was because I didn’t get to go out very often. After all, I mainly went there for school. The school made the experience terrible as I was bullied for being trans. None of the teachers would help me due to religious/scientistic beliefs. I was grateful that my school didn’t inforce AFAB (assigned female at birth) kids to wear skirts as it was the norm in that country. It was a culture that has been past on for years and I didn’t think that it was fair as I didn’t identify as female regardless of my biological sex. I guess the problem was that I was trans as none of this even happened to my older sisters. They were both cisgender females and I wasn’t, which was why I didn’t have a great time in my country. I came back to the UK crying my balls out begging my parents to never take me back to my country again and I can tell you right now, it was difficult. As I was always with my family when I go out, I was constantly deadnamed and misgendered. If I was in the UK, I could be by my own and wouldn’t have that problem. I have a question now, is there any LGBTQ+ folks that is from DR Congo?

You’d think so, based on the reaction I get when I tell people I’m from Denmark. It’s a very small country, but we do have the Little Mermaid statue – forever disappointing American tourists with her diminutive size – and we make a couple of fairly popular beers, so you might have heard of us even if you aren’t into history or geography. I’m going to give the American school system the benefit of doubt and assume that people outside of our impoverished country parish might have heard of Denmark, but around here I usually get one of two reactions: It’s either a blank stare or the assumption that I meant Denmark, Texas. Well, those are the reactions I get from people who accept that I’m an immigrant, but a good portion see my white skin and hear my southern drawl and assume that I’m joking. One woman checked my ID, when I only had my Danish license on me, and told me that if I was going to make a fake ID, I might as well make one from a real country. Hearing that you probably want to believe that she was joking, but her air of superiority and patronizing stare made it clear that she thought I was the idiot in that exchange. When someone finally accepts that I truly am from a place outside the US known as Denmark, they typically have no idea where that is. Another common reaction is the assumption that Denmark doesn’t have its own language. After all, the Danish (“Denmarkian”) person they’re looking at is speaking English at that moment, so that must be what we all speak, all the time. When people are familiar with Denmark, it’s usually because of something rather odd. One woman was apparently a huge fan of Sylvester Stallone, so she knew that Denmark was real because her hero had once been married to a woman who was from there. One guy followed soccer, so he knew Denmark was real because we had a team. The funniest one was a little Asian dude who worked for the USCIS. Like many of their employees, he was clearly an immigrant himself, but on one of my last visits to their office (I am citizen now), he saw on the form that I was from Denmark and immediately got excited and asked me if I had any of those sugar cookies with me. You’ve probably seen the ones he meant, the “Royal Danish” in a blue tin? They actually are Danish, but it’s not something I carry around with me everywhere like a chapstick or an emergency tampon. It’s a bit weird, but I actually owe Donald Trump a thank you, because lately I don’t get the blank stare as much. It’s still not great, because now people hear the name “Denmark”, and their immediate response is to ask me, an average citizen who has lived abroad for more than a decade, why we won’t sell Greenland.

response.answer_text: The country I come from is called Lebanon, and no not Lebanon Pennsylvania, or Lebanon Illinois, or Lebanon South Dakota, or any of the several other towns and isolated hamlets throughout the USA that bear the same name, but the country called Lebanon. Wondering where that might be?  Pretty cute huh? Now I know what your thinking Its in the Middle East?! Or in other words, a desert, terrorist hotspot, towel head homeland. (Personally I hate using the latter term) But…    Yea we got snow too! So Lebanon is not a desert, it claims the wonderful Mediterranean climate, and has four seasons. I mean seriously, how can you miss the cedar tree in the national flag!?  hint hint? Now when the matter comes to terrorists, it is serious, or at least it was. Lebanon has had its streak of terrorist attacks, urban bombings, a potential ISIS invasion, but these are really over exaggerated. The last large scale bombing was a year ago, almost shares the same date as the Paris attack, remember #PrayForParis, bet you never heard of #PrayForBeirut. Lebanon is a victim to ISIS, but on a smaller scale compared to the UK, France, Germany, etc.  But the real threat comes from within, political parties find very ruthless ways with dealing with each other, and sometimes unfortunately claim innocent lives. Lebanon is intensively corrupt, laws are disregarded or altered, bribes are everyday events, but at least there is effort for change. This change is starting to show as Lebanon is a lot safer compared to it a decade ago. I mean compared to murders in USA, you’re safer here. You may have heard of Hezbollah, maybe as a terrorist organization or maybe as enemies of Israel, regardless media usually disregards the good things people have done. Now I am not a follower of any political party over here and I am not a fan of politics itself, but Hezbollah earns a bit of respect since they helped save Lebanon from being invaded from ISIS in 2014. That is something to be grateful for. Anyway out of politics since it isn't the most pleasant thing about Lebanon. Lebanon's culture is not that of the average Arab country, Lebanon’s culture isn't really average across the globe. In this mountainous land 10,452 sq km large, 18 different sects currently reside, notably Maronites and Druze. Both being local sects that have their own religion. Main sects in Lebanon are as follows: 27.6% Sunni Islam27.3% Shia Islam26.4% Catholic Church9.9% Eastern Oriental Orthodoxy1.2% Christian minorities5.7% Druze0.8% Alawite0.5% Evangelical0.1% OtherThat’s not all since Lebanon is clearly also very religiously diverse as well. Main religions in Lebanon are as follows: 27% Sunni27% Shia21% Maronite Catholic8% Greek Orthodox5.6% Druze(who do not consider themselves Muslims)5% Melkite Catholic1% Protestant(Thats me!)5.4% of various Christian denominations, such as Armenian Catholic, Armenian Orthodox, Syriac Catholic, Syriac Orthodox, Roman Catholic, Chaldean, Assyrian and Copt.Small amounts of Jews, Baha’is, Buddhists, Hindus and Mormons.Now with all this diversity, Lebanon's constitution was made to ensure the peaceful cohabitation of all different sects and religions living in the country. A prime example being that the President must be a Christian, while the Prime minister must be a Muslim. The parliament ensures that everyone will be represented and has a word in governing the country. In principle this should create a secularized society, but that really depends on the person him/herself and more than often religious differences spill into open conflict. When you ask one where they are from, you are really asking what is their sect and religion, as religious groups usually live in areas with the same dominant religion. Just look at a map of the distribution of various religious groups  (I live in that yellow spot east of Beirut) Asking someone about their sect or religion is also a very sensitive topic since such things deeply influenced events during the 1975–1990 Lebanese civil war, which managed to kill 120.000, wound 300.000 and drive out 800.000 very well educated people to more enlightened areas of the world, and the scars still show physically throughout the landscape and mentally. But compared to our neighbors, Lebanon is the most religiously secularized country in the middle east.  Phew, now that that’s cleared, wanna know about the good things? FOOD! Thats the first thing anyone has to experience in Lebanon, even if you have a layover in the airport, get out and taste the mouth watering traditional goodness that makes this country what it is. Everything from cheesy sweets to zucchini stuffed with meat and liquorice liquor. Every single piece of food completely enhances the capability of your taste buds.   I can seriously just sit all day and post pictures of Lebanese food but it still wont describe the perfectly crafted taste that is non reproducible in any part of the globe other than Lebanon. I haven't met one foreigner with the biggest smile on his/her face after leaving a restaurant, I also haven't met one person that left Lebanon constantly complain about missing the food, including myself! So just book yourself a flight and taste the food, and trust me its completely worth it. (I bet you’re hungry right now) Nightlife I mean if you look up any article about nightlife your always most probably going to find Beirut in there, it even tops Las Vegas in some articles. Beirut is a city that never sleeps, its nightlife is as busy as its daylife(if that's a word), and for a country in the Middle East, the people here are very open, quite literally when it comes to clothing. You know life is good when you eat delicious breakfast after a whole night partying.  And finally Sites/History Lebanon’s history is incredibly rich, it was inhabited by the Phoenicians back in 1500BC and invaded several times through its existence. The Phoenicians themselves were naval trade experts and colonized multiple regions in Cyprus, Italy, North Africa and Spain. The great leader Hannibal was of Phoenician decent, and he took his forefathers naval expertise with him to battle(beat that Romans). The city Byblos is also one of the world’s oldest continuously inhabited cities. The Phoenicians are also credited with creating the first modern alphabet. This is my life 99% of time  Scenario 1: Them: So where are you from? You have a bit of an accent. *Should I lie and say I’m from Poland so we are done with this?* Me: Lithuania Them: Li…what? Me: Lithuania, Lituania, Litauen, Litwa, Litva, リトアニア. It’s a country next to Poland. Them: Ah, Poland. I know Poland! Them: Aren’t you part of Russia though? Me: Not since 1991 Them: Ah.  Scenario 2: Them: So where are you from? You have a bit of an accent. Me: Lithuania Them: Ah! Sabonis. Ilgauskas. Songaila. Marčiulionis! Me: Hey, you watch NBA? Yeah, they’re pretty big. Them: Aren’t you part of Russia though? Me: ….  Scenario 3: Them: So where are you from? Me: Lithuania Them: Ah, I know Riga! I went there for a holiday six years ago Me: Close, but that’s Latvia, a different country. Lithuania is right next to Latvia. Them: Aren’t you part of Russia though? Me: Weren’t you in the region?  Scenario 4: Them: So where are you from? Me: Europe Them: But which country? Me: hmm….Poland Them: Aren’t you part of Russia though? Me :……..  I don’t mind explaining where I’m from. Lithuanians are under no delusion that people know where our tiny country is on the map. Just look at the global tourism campaign for our capital city, Vilnius:  However, for the love of God, please brush up on your world history. Dissolution of the Soviet Union happened in 1991; 27 years ago. Russia is a massive country; there is no excuse for not knowing that the USSR is not a thing anymore. It’s a painful part of our history, and we don’t necessarily want to be reminded of it every single time.

I’m not, but many of my friends are. Here are some conversations I’ve had with multiple people about their countries of origin: Me: Are you half-black? Friend: No, I’m from Trinidad. Me: The island in the Caribbean? Friend: Yeah! Most people have never heard of it. One person asked if it was by Madagascar!  (Riding an Uber) Me: So where are you from? Driver: I am originally from Burkina Faso! Me: …Is the capital Ouagadougou? Driver: YES! How do you know that? Me: I heard it on TV once… Driver: That is interesting. Here in America, nobody knows where that is. In Texas, people ask me where I am from, so I say “Burkina Faso”. They say “What? Where is that?” so I just say “Oh, it’s in West Texas.” And they say “Oh, okay…” HAHA!  (Meeting someone for the first time) Me: So where are you from? Him: I am originally from Estonia. Me (trying to sound smarter than I actually am): …North or south? Him: It is just Estonia…  On a personal note, my mother is from Taiwan, which is fairly obscure to many of my friends:  Not many people know about it, but there’s a large Taiwanese community where I live and you see Taiwan mentioned often in movies and TV so more and more people hear about it.

Ohhhhhh yes. I am from Malta. One of the tiniest Countries in Europe, Only Beaten by Monaco ,Vatican City,Liechenstein and Monaco. Malta was THE most Bombed Country in World War 2 with over 14,000 Bombs dropped and almost 30,000 Building gone. One of the most Important Dates is The Great Siege this took place in 1565 when the Knights of St John where occupying Malta, The Mighty Ottoman Empire had taken over the last Home of the Knights which was the Island of Rhodes, now that were about to do the same it took 3 months,3 Weeks and 3 Days and almost 7,000 Civilians Dead and 2,500 Knights gone but they somehow managed to beat the Ottoman army of 10,000 to 35,000. it was not just the Knights but the Spanish who had given the Knight the new home with the payment of 1 Maltese Falcon per Year had helped out the Knight in the End of the War  Our National Animal is Actually called the Pharoah Hound which looks a bit like this  Other Animals Include the  The Blue Rock Trush  The Maltese Wall Lizard(Myths say that a Sub Species that lives on Fungus Rock has Two Heads)  The Maltese Ruby Tiger Moth  And in Number 1 THE MALTESE FALCON PLACES YOU SHOULD VISIT Mnajdra  Hagar Qim  Ghar Dalam  Hypogeum of Hal-Saflieni  St John Cathedral   and WAY TOO MUCH OTHER PLACES TO MENTION well that is it for now but 2 more things before I go. See this weirdly shaped country with an awesome looking flag?   You probably don’t know much or you have never heard of CROATIA. I get it. We are pretty small country and have only 4.224 million inhabitants. Oh, and that weird shape? Result of a long and tough history. Don’t even ask… We are located in southeast Europe.  What to say about such a small and beautiful country with own complicated language? I could go on and on but I will try to make it simple. You sure know about about this guy, Nikola Tesla.  Man who was of great importance in fields such as physics and electrotehnics, was born in Croatia, in Smiljan. We are really proud of him. You also know about Game of thrones  Yes, some scenes were filmed here, in Dubrovnik.   I would also say we are known for our interesting and unique soccer jerseys.  Mario Mandžukić, Luka Modrić, Darijo Srna, Ivan Rakitić… Maybe you heard some of these names if you are into soccer. And not to forget the greatest basketball player in Croatian history, Dražen Petrović, who was playing for NBA.  Neckties! Kravate!  The modern necktie traces back to the time of the Thirty Years’ War (1618–1648) when Croatian mercenaries in French service were wearing their traditional small, knotted neckerchiefs. Due to the slight difference between the Croatian word for Croats, Hrvati, and the French word, Croates, the garment gained the name "cravat" ("cravate" in French). On the occasion of his visit to Zadar, in May 1964, Alfred Hitchcock stated that this town has the most beautiful sunset in the world. I have seen it myself and it really is breathtaking.  I could go on but there is so much to write about. Instead, take a look at this pictures I think represent Croatia at its best. My country is unknown except for donations and lost planes. I live here. The 3rd largest island in the world, Borneo. I live in the Malaysian part, Sarawak to be precise. Have anyone heard of this island before? No? Oh well so today I’ll be talking about this island. Borneo is located in Southeast Asia and is shared between 3 countries i.e Brunei, Indonesia (Kalimantan), and Malaysia (Sabah, Sarawak). It is a very biodiverse place, with thousands of species of plants and animals equivalent to that of Amazon, and lots of them are undiscovered yet. It is composed of 2,636,000 people of 30+ different ethnic groups, each with their own culture and language. Iban people is the majority here, followed by Chinese and then Malay. Regarding religion, 42% of the population adheres to Christianity, 30% are Muslims, Buddhist is the 3rd largest religion, followed by animism, irreligion/atheism, and lastly Hinduism. Despite the diverse background of our people, we live in peace. I mean it. Everyone is united. I could say this is where faith in humanity can be restored. In my hometown, a mass iftar (breaking of fast in Ramadan) was held and invites everyone from all walks of life including the non-Muslims. There was also a church organized an iftar event last year. Christmas carolling also can be held peacefully. Kuching, the capital city, is recognized as the City of Unity by the federal government and also the cleanest city in Malaysia.  So colourful !!  Kuching, the capital of Sarawak. To the left is the State Legislative Assembly building, amd the right is the central business district. You may think Borneo is mainly nothing but rainforests and animals, but we are more than that. Thanks to the booming economy of Malaysia, we are not left behind in terms of globalization. We know what is going on around the world e.g wars, terrorism, concerts, celebrities etc. The federal government also has allocated RM27 billion to upgrade our current intercity highway from a single carriageway to a limited-access dual carriageway with controlled-access features but a lower speed limit. We also have H&M, 7-Eleven, Starbucks and lots more international stores. Regarding social issues, just like is most parts of Asia, LGBTQ+ is not widely accepted here. However, the trans community are slowly being accepted among the society but not the others. The people living in urban areas (Kuching, Miri, Sibu, Bintulu) tend to be more open-minded and less homophobic. Teenagers’ are given freedom to go out and do whatever they want, but no parties at late night. (Please note that this is my observation only). Before ending my answer, I’d like to present to you the natures of Sarawak. It’s only pictures with some captions, because the nature is so breathtaking, can’t be expressed by words. (Images are courtesy of google)  Food nature? Well the Sarawakian pride, Laksa Sarawak !  Mulu Caves, the biggest cave system in the world. It could fit lots of Boeing 747s in it.  Bako National Park, the smallest national park in Sarawak.  Batang Ai lake.  Tusan Beach. The beach has bioluminescence phenomena and it glows at night, just like you have in Maldives.  Kelabit Highlands. Well i think this is the end of my answer. Come to Sarawak to experience the warmth and hospitality of our people. You wouldn’t regret it :) Edit: i feel bad for not posting the pictures of our nature because it’s so amazing. Edit 2: Wow thanks for 7.5K views. This is my 2nd answer on Quora :) Edit 3: Well if you have a question just ask me in the comments below :) Any edits are welcome

Hello, My name is Mumble, alias happy feet.  As you may have noticed, I’m a penguin.I live in the Sandwich Islands. No, no joke, that’s actually their name. That good old James Cook who discovered us had a great sense of humor. Or some food issues. We’re in the Southern Atlantic ocean, South-East of Latin America (South Georgia and Sandwich Islands territories).  My island has zero permanent human inhabitants. Here us pinguins are kings. As any good Monarch we also have many subjects living among us, a vast variety of other birds: petrels, shags, gulls, terns, prions, albatross… During its life, an albatross travels 24M km (36 times the Earth-moon distance). And somehow they choose my place as their headquarter. That’s how cool my island is. We also allow some seals, elephant seals to come tan on our beaches (it’s not like if those hobos had a job or anything else to do anyways).  Technically my island belongs to the UK thus making me a British penguin. Sometimes I have dreams involving teabags, it may explain it. We also somehow have one church, because, as everybody knows, penguins are christians. No really, it’s a remain of the old whaling stations all over the islands, back in times. Uncool…But thank god, now that hunting them is forbbidden, the whale population has risen again and nature has reclaimed its rights, the only building left are the remainings of those abandonned whale stations. With their new inhabitants:  We do not have any city hall, post office, supermarket, mini golf (…), but we somehow have our own postage stamp. Really useful when I sell my old fishing books on ebay. Our military is made up of several british naval vessels patrolling the region several times a year, maintaining law and order, protecting our borders from all those illegal human migrants trying to invade us and steal our jobs (tanning in the sun, professional sledders and of course tap dancers).Since, seeing it as a thriving sector, some penguins have converted into google earth drivers, you can now even wander around my island online -> google EarthDon’t mind those humans around, they are just tourists or scientists taking pictures of us, their idole, their god. So here it is, my little safe heaven. Time for me to leave you guys, maybe I’ll see some of you travellers passing by someday (in a protective/respectfull of my environment way of course) ;)

I am not myself from anywhere special, but I'd like to share about the Luchu Kingdom. Today, I think, for the most part, if anyone (in the English-speaking world, especially in the US) knows about Okinawa at all, they maybe know about the Battle of Okinawa, during WWII, and they likely think of Okinawa as just another part of Japan. But, up until the 1870s - less than 150 years ago - Okinawa was an independent kingdom. Known as Loochoo (or Luchu) in the native Okinawan language, the kingdom (known as Ryukyu in Japanese) was a Confucian kingdom, heavily influenced by Japan and by Qing Dynasty China, but also totally distinct. Much like Korea, it was its own separate culture and country within the East Asian “family” of cultures. The main island of Okinawa was ruled by three kingdoms in the 14th century, all three of which entered into close relationships with Ming China at the end of thst century, and began adopting Ming-style government, Confucian philosophy, architecture, arts, etc etc. One of the three kingdoms, Chûzan, conquered the other two and united the island under its rule by 1429. It then expanded over the course of the 16th century, placing many of the islands to the north (the Amamis, etc) and all the islands to the south (the Miyako and Yaeyamas), almost to Taiwan, either under some sort of tributary relationship, or conquering them outright. During this period, the Kingdom, though small, developed into a very significant entrepot (intermediate trading center), with Luchuan, Korean, Chinese, Japanese, and Southeast Asian ships, goods, and/or merchants regularly passing through the kingdom's bustling port of Naha. Ryukyu was invaded in 1609 by forces from the samurai domain of Satsuma (Kagoshima), and from that time forward became a tributary or vassal or something under Satsuma (historians still debate just how to name, or characterize this relationship). But in many important ways, the kingdom remained independent. It maintained its close relationship with China, as it always had, on the basis of being a sovereign kingdom. And while increased Japanese cultural influence was inevitable in certain ways, the kingdom very much continued to have its own distinct, distinctly Ryukyuan, culture. They continued to have kings on the throne, and their own Confucian scholar - aristocracy - based government, and there were never more than a handful of Japanese resident in the kingdom at any time. In the 1800s, the kingdom signed formal Treaties with the US, France, Britain, and the Netherlands, but by 1879 (at the end of a really interesting but complicated set of diplomatic incidents and tensions between China and Japan), Tokyo unilaterally declared the Kingdom abolished and its lands annexed. The royal bureaucracy, strangely enough, remained active into the early years of the 20tg century in certain respects, and Okinawa remains quite distinct culturally even today. But, it wasn't that long ago that Luchu was an independent, sovereign, kingdom unto itself, with its own vibrant traditions and noble history.

I’m going to spare a fact or two about Estonia.   Looking at the map, one might wonder how we live.   We still possess the legacy of medieval period such as the Old Town in the capital city Tallinn.  Did you know that the St. Olaf’s church was supposedly the highest building in 1549–1625?  Although we might be Europe’s peripheral area, we are leading in IT sector (Skype is made in Estonia). Estonians are voting, paying taxes and doing pretty much everything via internet. Moving everything to the online world is easy, because our population is plummeting every year. In the future, we are hopefully preserved in virtual reality.   We are a nation of sporting as there are quite few obese people compared to other Western nations. Kiiking and woman carrying originated from here.  Besides getting physical, we love singing. As the Soviet Union was on the verge of collapse in the late 1980s, the Singing Revolution peacefully helped us to regain our independence in 1991.  It was the short story of my home as I saved the violent history for another day.

I come from Pakistan, that tiny country squished between Afghanistan and India In the internet i never tell people where i am from anymore, because apparently the word Pakistan brings in the worst in trolls.. Offline i ever tell anyone where i am from, either i get an “ohh” as if “i dont know where the hell that is, but i am too embarassed to ask” or they ask me where it is. I legit had a world geography teacher, i repeat, world geography teacher, tell me that Pakistan and Palestine are two different names for the same country. Then he thought that its next to Saudia, pulls up Saudia on a map and starts looking for Pakistan [how he jumped from Pakistan and Palestine to being the same to Pakistan being next to Saudia, i have no idea]. After he kept searching, i thought, let me tell him, so I say to him “Pakistan is next to India” His response? “That is not possible”. When i tell him to pull up the map and see he goes “I am pretty sure its not next to India” I guess that means my whole life was a lie because all this time I had my country’s geographical location all wrong. As I am easily amused, I always say “Pakistan is next to Iraq” whenever asked. Just for fun. They always believe it. Its evil, i know

I am from Armenia! I wouldnt say no one knows it exists but it is a relatively unknown country, especially outside of ex Soviet Union countries! There are various misconceptions about us but today I will try to introduce you to Hayastan!(Thats how we call our country in Armenian).  Armenia is located in a geographical area which is called South Caucasus and we share common borders with Georgia, Azerbaijan, Iran and Turkey. There are about 3 million people living in Republic of Armenia, however there are about 11 million Armenians all over the World. The largest communities of Armenians live in Russia, The USA and France. Majority of people here belong to Apostolic Church!  Armenian church is called Apostolic because Thadeus and Bartolomeo apostles of Jesus Christ came here in the first century to spread Christianity and this is the place where we believe they met each other.  Armenia became a Christian country in 301 and after that a lot of monasteries have been built here. The one in the picture is Tatev monastery built in 9th century!  We are also a country of the coolest revolution of 2018! It is true, Foreign medias didnt pay much attention it because Armenia isnt that popular but we still are proud that we were able to overthrow a corrupt government by peaceful and non violent movement through the whole country!  We danced our way to revolution!  We showed that this is revolution of love  We showed the power of people! I think there is some beauty about not being so popular or a well known country. Let me explain. It is really a great feeling when people just find out about your country and culture, you just become a discovery for them!  Thanks for attention!

The country I’m from is called Moldova. I’ve met very few people to have heard about this country at least (partially because it used to be a part of the Soviet Union and only gained its independence around 25 years ago).  It is located in Eastern Europe, in between Ukraine and Romania. Since we were once a part of Dacia (later Romania), have the same language and culture, most of the people living here (except for the Russians living here and other minorities) are considered to be ethnically Romanian. That’s why I jokingly reffer to our country as “Romania Jr.”, only to avoid the confusion some foreigners may have when asking me where I’m from. The only time our country is mentioned on an international scale is at the Eurovision. It is also worth mentioning that Moldova is the country of origin of the Epic Sax Guy  and O Zone’s “Dragostea din tei”  Moreover, we’re considered the country with the biggest amount of alcohol consumed per capita. And so, cheers! Or as we say it here - Noroc! EDIT: I feel ashamed not to have mentioned our wines. And for this reason, I present to you The State Enterprise Quality Wines Industrial Complex "Mileștii Mici", which is registered to be the biggest wine collection in the world.  EDIT NR.2: This music video called “My Moldova” showcases our landscapes and some of our culture, alongside a generally good song  And also this video that sums up our country in a comedic way

I was born in a country called Qatar. I now live in Australia and whenever somebody asks me where I was born and I say Qatar, most of them have no clue on which country I’m talking about. Qatar is a country located in Western Asia. It’s neighbouring country is Saudi Arabia and Bahrain. Qatar has got a population of nearly 2.7 million people. In size it is roughly as big as the US state of Connecticut. Oil-rich Qatar is the richest country in the world before Luxemburg, although it is one of the smallest countries in the world. In fact, the people in Qatar are the richest in the world. Many famous buildings in London/England such as The Shard and Harrods are owned at least in part by Qatari citizens! About 14% of the Qatari are millionaires. Qataris dress modestly, and this is also asked from tourists. Women are required to cover their skin and should not wear miniskirts, leggings or sleeveless tops and dresses men should not wear are shorts and sleeveless t-shirts. Qatar has a different working week than other western countries. The work week runs from Sundays to Thursdays, as their shops are usually closed on Fridays and Saturdays. Shops are usually open in the morning until noon and then close for a long lunch break and only open in the late afternoon again. The most popular sports in the country are soccer, handball and tennis. In 2010, Qatar won the bid to host the 2022 World Cup, although many accusation were made against it. For the World Cup, they are building a new airport, sea ports, hotels and even a city!! An image below shows construction of the new city Lusail City  Pretty cool, right? They also own Qatar Airways. Here are some pics of Qatar      Sorry for the spam of pictures :)

I’m from a small island that hardly anyone knows exists, located next to a bigger island that is world famous. You see, I was born on the Isle of Pines (Isla de Pinos; no, it was not named after my family), located just south of Havana province in Cuba. Our island has been largely unknown throughout history—-one big reason it was always popular with pirates. Isla de Pinos became part of the Republic of Cuba in 1902, although the U.S. gave serious consideration to annexing the island. We never got big enough to become a province, only an adjunct to Havana. Then, in 1978 Dr. Fidel Castro, in his infinite wisdom, decided to change the name of our beloved homeland to the Isle of Youth (Isla de la Juventud). But, to us “Pineros” it will always remain Isle of Pines 4ever!

I’m not but my mum is. My mum is from Mauritius! It’s a tiny island in the Indian Ocean, to the east of Madagascar and to the south of Seychelles.  This is where Mauritius is on a map and in relation to some other Indian Ocean islands.  And here’s a close up of Mauritius. The village in the north of Mauritius, Goodlands, is circled because it is where my mum was born. Almost all of my Mauritian family live in Goodlands. I’ve only been to Mauritius twice as it’s 6000 miles away from England and it’s really expensive to travel there (Mauritius). Mauritius has had a dark history of being colonised by several European powers; namely: the Netherlands, France and Britain. In the 17th century, the Dutch came to Mauritius and colonised it. Unfortunately, the native bird, the dodo (yes the dodo was native to Mauritius) became extinct as they were all killed and eaten. Since there were no major predators for the dodos to worry about, they are thus not able to fly. This made them vulnerable, should predators come to Mauritius. However, the Dutch abandoned Mauritius, causing the French to come over and colonise it. They renamed Mauritius to ‘Île Maurice’. Mauritian Creole gets a lot of its vocabulary from the French language, and the two languages are almost mutually intelligible. In 1810, during the time of the Napoleonic Wars, Britain colonised Île Maurice and renamed it ‘Mauritius’. It was known as ‘The Star and Key of the Indian Ocean’. On 12th March 1968, gained independence and in 1992, it became a republic. This is the flag of Mauritius:  Today, Mauritius is the most developed African country, in terms of its economy and democracy. It goes without saying that Mauritius has beautiful beaches and beautiful scenery. Here are some photos which I took when I went there in 2015.      As you can see in the final photo, French is widely spoken in Mauritius. However, languages like English, Hindi and Bhojpuri are also widely spoken and understood. If visiting a tropical island interests you, then you should visit Mauritius. It’s absolutely idyllic and the locals are really nice as well! However, in Goodlands, I had to stay with a family member at all times as I’d come across as a rich European tourist. This was especially since my uncle’s motorbike was stolen during our visit, and there was a lot of pick-pocketing activities going on.

I don’t live in these nations but I’ve come across many people (both in person and online) who have never heard of them. Lesotho and Swaziland Let’s start with Lesotho. Lesotho is completely surrounded by South Africa - it’s South Africa-locked to be precise! This is one of the very seldom-seen phenomena in the entire world! To make matters worse for it, it’s very small (30 355 square kilometers; if it was a province of South Africa it rank eight out of nine). It has also has a small population of 2 203 821. Also, its dominant language, SeSotho, is also an official language in South Africa. It’s completely depended on South Africa for its total existence!  The there is Swaziland. Swaziland’s case is a bit better than that of Lesotho because it shares a tiny border with Mozambique to the east, but to the north, west, south and southeast it’s bordered by South Africa. It’s even more smaller than Lesotho (17 364 square kilometers; if it was a province of South Africa, it would the smallest). It has a tiny population of 1 343 098. It’s dominant language, SiSwati is also and official language in South Africa. It’s also completely depended on South Africa for its total existence!

Malaysia - Wikipedia It is very normal that certain towns or cities are full of students as customers instead of working adults, as there might be more universities or colleges around the area. I don’t hail from this country, but I'd love if more & more people get to know about this beautiful country. The country of Andorra.  16th smallest country in the world by size & 11th smallest by population, just a 40 km drive will take you from one side of the country to another.  Some interesting facts about the country: Andorra has never been in a war in almost 1,000 years!Andorra has no national bank and has never had its own currency - It uses Euro as official currency though not being part of EU, EFTA or the Eurozone.Andorra has the 8th highest life expectancy in the world - 83 years!Andorra is the world’s only co-principality - Meaning it has two princes who jointly share the title of prince. Surprisingly, neither of the two princes are from Andorra. One prince is the President of France, Emmanuel Macron. The other co-prince is the Bishop of Urgell(a county in Spain).

I'm from Singapore. In 2004 my company sent me to Dallas Texas on a 5 month work assignment. Other than the colleagues there, I had the idea most people do not know Singapore exists. I am from Kenya. A country in East Africa. Some people may have heard of Kenya, Some people may have not. You may recognize Kenya from its success in producing award winning Athletes or from Obama’s birthplace scandal or from Tv documentaries about Wildlife and Maasai lives. Kenya was a colony of Britain until we gain independence in 1963. The Great Rift Valley passes through the country creating beautiful sceneries and so many lakes. We also have Savanna grasslands with World famous game parks like Maasai Mara. Our neighbors include Somalia, Ethiopia, Tanzania and South Sudan. You may have seen Kenyan Coffee at your local Starbucks. Yes it was produced in Kenya. Same as Kenyan tea.  This is Kenya on the Map. Is there anybody on Quora who have never heard of Kenya, really?. I know Kenya is pretty known but I thought I should share about where I am from.

Not a country, I’m from the USA, but I’m from a state that no one know exists, the State of Jefferson. The State of Jefferson is a secessionist movement in northern California and southern Oregon that came about before WWII. The movement was put on hold to support the war effort, and has existed mostly in bars until now. The crux of the movement is that these rural areas feel that they are not fairly represented by state governments that are dominated by more urban areas. The election of a madman for President has re-kindled the movement. Take a peek, we make a lot of sense.

I would be wrong to say none. But most don't. Generally when I am traveling abroad, usual conversations go like this: ~ Hey, where are you from? ~ Uzbekistan! ~ Pakistan?!! ~ Uzbekistan!!! ~Yoozbekistan?/ujbakistan? Uzpakistan? ~Never mind. It is in Asia. Within Uzbekistan we have an autonomous country called Karakalpakstan and if they ever chose to become an independent country, they would for sure be mistaken for Pakistan. And their introductions would be much worse: ~ I am from Karakalpakstan. ~Pakistan? ~ Karakalpakstan!!!! ~Kara… what?!!! Is it in Pakistan!? ~ Ka- Ra- Kal - Pa- Ki- Stan ~ *gives up* You can continue reading if you didn't know about Uzbekistan. We're located in the center of Central Asia. Population is 32+ million and its growth rate is unstoppable. Some facts below:  Mostly “-stan” is stereotypically known as Muslim Country. In some context it is true for us because we have majority Muslims. But on the other hand, it is not a typical Muslim Country. We have over 130 ethnicities living in one country practicing whatever faith they belong to. As soon as you land in Tashkent (capital), your first impression may be as if you visited post-apocalyptic country. Why? Because we don't have tall skyscrapers and dense population. The roads are emptier comparing to other countries.    But, that's not really bad thing. We almost never worry about traffic. Never! You can easily drive 70km/h throughout the city. Historically we were more settled than our neighbors. Because of that architecture became one of the highlights of Uzbekistan. We have 3 major historical cities and they’ve been getting attention of travelers lately. Samarkand - ex Capital   2. Bukhara    3 . Khiva    Edit: Thank you for overwhelmingly positive response. I am very humbled. Many of you asked about safety. And I can assure you it is pretty safe here. Crime rate is low. I would get in trouble if I messed with a tourist, no joke. We have a saying, a guest is greater than your father. (Treat your guest better than your father). And I did a little bit research, and according to Gallup Peace, Security Still Out of Reach for Many Worldwide Uzbekistan is in the top 5 safest countries.  Edit: Specially for my Indian fellows. If you've got time, you can watch this video. I know it is old but it's pretty great documentary.  Thanks for reading :)

I am from a small principality in what is now the Federal Republic of Germany, which was free and independent (my grandfather had to change his citizenship to be able to serve in the Kaiser’s army in WWI) until 1918, when the local prince was forced to abdicate and the principality was incorporated into the Weimar Republic, even though it retained its status as a “Freistaat” (comparable to a US state) until 1947, when the British occupying authority forced the “Freistaat Lippe” into the larger unit of North-Rhine Westphalia. A plebiscite was promised at that time, but, as was to be expected, the politicians saw to it that the people never were allowed to vote. To free my beloved homeland, in which the prince is still residing in his castle and I still have a house, I have decided to form a government in exile on my California ranch. Our goal is to reclaim our independence and to get Lippe out of the EU.

Willemstad, Curaçao  My country is a small country in the Caribbean Sea north of the coast of Venezuela. We are part of the ABC islands which includes Aruba and Bonaire. Little facst about Curaçao: • We are fluent in 4 languages Papiamentu (mixture of Spanish and Portuguese);Dutch;Spanish andEnglish.• We have crystalline beaches   • We are known for “Our Swinging Old Lady” which is the Queen Emma Bridge. The bridge swings open when a boat enters or leaves the harbor.  • We have a mini island called “Klein Curaçao” (Small Curaçao). It's an 1.7 square kilometres uninhabited island south-east of Curaçao. The only structures on the island are an old lighthouse, a beach house, and several huts. Klein Curaçao is well known as a beautiful diving-spot because of its coral and underwater caves. It's fairly easy to spot colorful fish and sea turtles when snorkeling.      • Curaçao liqueur The famous “Blue Curacao” is made in Curaçao.   • UNESCO includes the harbor and the historic city in the list of World Heritage Sites.

The country I will talk about is not unknown (mostly in its history), though most foreigners (like Americans, Brazilians, Danish, etc) simply cannot tell easily many things about my country, Greece ;)   Greece is located in Southeast Europe and the crossroads of Europe, Asia, and Africa!! It’s not densely populated, because only 10.7 million people live here. I’m 100% sure that you know our landmark, don’t you?  (Parthenon, of course) (Now something funny); I was once talking with a Brazilian internet friend, and when I told her I am from Greece, she asked me the following; In Greece, do you believe in Zeus?!! Well…  Haha of course not! Greek religion nowadays is Orthodox Christianity (mostly, there is also a Muslim minority in Thrace and many Muslims all around Greece)  (the small “church” outside Monastiraki station in Athens) Now, I should talk to you about the best thing, food!! Greece is so popular about products produced here (and for some meals, of course)  These are; 1. Strained (Greek) Yoghurt 2. Greek Red Saffron (Kozani Saffron) 3. Feta Cheese 4. Moussakas (usually based on sautéed aubergine (eggplant) and tomato) 5. Gyros (if you ever visit Greece is a must-eat fast food) 6. Olive oil The reason I write this answer is that most people know about Athens and Greek popular isles (Santorini, Mykonos, Crete, Zakynthos, Corfu, Rhodes). Greece is not only that! In Greece every region has, it’s own beauty!  Thessaloniki, the “συμπρωτεύουσα” (second capital) of Greece (in the background you can see the White Tower of Thessaloniki)  Zagorochoria or Zagori Villages, located in Epirus, in North-western Greece (worth reading about those. Zagori - Wikipedia)  Symi island, located in South-eastern Greece, 3.7 miles away from Turkey  Komotini, a city located in Thrace, North-eastern Greece. There is a big Muslim minority.  Trikala city, located in Central Greece. The - so-called - Greek “Smart City”. I would suggest you read these 2 articles; 1) Inside Greece's first smart city: 'Now you don't need to know a politician to get something done' 2) How Trikala Became The First Smart City Of Greece?  Meteora, a majestic mountain complex, just a few kilometers away from Trikala! Meteora - Wikipedia. It is also included in the UNESCO World Heritage list! Island of Borneo, most people (non-geographers) have never heard of it, in fact, my geography teacher only knew it because he studied world war 2 and the country I'm from, Australia, so happened to fight there. Right now I am incapable of posting pictures so here is a description: It's a combination of parts of Malaysia and Indonesia. When people think Malaysia they think Kuala Lumpur or, to a lesser extent, Penang. However, I come from Kuching, Sarawak, a lesser known state located on Borneo, and, thus, identify as malaysian (despite much racism from the Malays towards chinese-malays like myself but that's unimportant). Similarly, underneath Sarawak is a part of Indonesia (of which I am unclear of the name), which is often neglected in favour of larger cities like Jakarta and tourist favourite Bali. This island is also the third Largest island after Greenland and New Guinea so I'm relatively surprised of how little people know of it. While there are still many primitive communities on Borneo, called “kampongs” society, while looking somewhat like slums, has parts that are sophisticated. So there it is, the jungles of Borneo, in a nutshell. Edit: Smaller than Greenland and New Guinea! (Credit to Bohdan Barylko)

Oh look, an opportunity to be extremely patriotic… But I’ll do something a bit different. Czech republic. My first arrival in Moscow was on 2016 i was entering and traveling around Europe using a TIMOR-LESTE 🇹🇱 Passport ( Right no one knows about this country) , I was detained for almost 5 hours in the imigration, i was questioned by the Police what my country is, who us the president, where is located, What language use in your country. Here is the example of our passport  Yeah it is writing in Portuguese because our official language is Portuguese because we were one of Portuguese colonial , we got our independence on 2002 All about Timor-Leste 🇹🇱 Timor-Leste officially the Democratic Republic of Timor-Leste is a country in South East Asia . It comprises the eastern half of the island of Timor, the nearby islands of Atauro and Jaco, and Oecusse, an exclave on the northwestern side of the island surrounded by Indonesian West Timor. Australia is the country's southern neighbour, separated by the Timor Sea. The country's size is about 15,007 km East Timor was colonised by Portugal in the 16th century, and was known as Portuguese Timor until 28 November 1975, when the Revolutionary Front for an Independent East Timor (Fretilin) declared the territory's independence. Nine days later, it was invaded and occupied by the Indonesian military, and was declared as the country's 27th province the following year. The Indonesian occupation of East Timor was characterised by a highly violent, decades-long conflict between separatist groups (especially Fretilin) and the Indonesian military In 1999, following the United Nations-sponsored act of self-determination, Indonesia relinquished control of the territory. East Timor became the first new sovereign state of the 21st century on 20 May 2002 and joined the United Nations and the Community of Portuguese Language Countries. In 2011, East Timor announced its intention to become the eleventh member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN). It is one of only two predominantly Christian nations in Southeast Asia, the other being the Philippines, as well as the only Asian country to be located completely in the Southern Hemispheres . So I was born and raised in England, but I’m of mixed ethnicity. My dad is from Ghana in West Africa, a country basically everyone knows so no problems there. I'm sure that most people never heard of a small country located in the heart of South America, which borders Brazil, Argentina & Bolivia.  I'm talking about Paraguay. Most people in Paraguay live in the capital and nearby cities which are called Greater Asunción.   Another city here - Ciudad del Este. You may have heard of it if you've heard of The Triple Frontier. It's next to the Brazilian city of Foz de Iguaçu.   The most beautiful city in Paraguay (for me), Encarnación. It borders the Argentinian city of Posadas.   Some landmarks: Monday Falls.  Jesuit Ruins.  Biggest hydroelectric dam is located here:  Some Paraguayan dishes: Enpanadas:  The only solid soup you'll ever taste:  National drink, Tereré.  Come to visit! It’s a beautiful country.

Me - New Zealand *Stranger is confused* Stranger- Where is that? Me - Off the coast of Australia? I am originally from Wisconsin, which I never thought of as particularly exotic. And it’s not.  It’s tucked under Lake Superior in the northern Midwest. There some difference in geography. In the north, there’s a lot of tree. In the south, there’s lot of farms and rolling hills. When I was about ten, we moved (long story) to Kwajalein, in the Marshall Islands.    It was a military base. It would be my first winter without frozen lakes and my first adventures in saltwater swimming. The first day of school, I met a girl and told her I was from Wisconsin. She was American, from a military family. She gave me a blank look and said, “Never heard of the place.”

When we first got a job offer to this country, we were bewildered. Because though we were not so bad at geography in school, we had never heard of it before. Now this country has been our home for the past 4 years. It is a tiny country sandwiched between the mammoth Democratic Republic of Congo and Tanzania - Burundi. Even now if someone asks us back home where you are living, I find it easier to say East Africa. Because for some reason everytime I say Burundi, people hear it as Brunei. And Brunei is very famous in India because of the distinction held by the Sultan of being the richest man in the world once upon a time. It is a beautiful place, with its capital Bujumbura situated on the banks of the world's second largest lake - Lake Tanganyika. It is so huge, that you have waves like you are in a beach.  This lake which also has the distinction of the longest freshwater lake in the world, spans across 4 countries in Africa.  Some in Burundi also claim that it was here that the iconic words “Dr. Livingston, I presume” was uttered by the explorer Henry Morton Stanley. Even if not so, it is surely a land which was part of that exploration.  Burundi drummers are an integral part of the culture here.

A state in US, next to California! Them: Oh really? Wow! Me: No it's a country to the tip of Australia! Them: You're Australian? Me: No we are neighbors Them: Oh but you are not white! Brunei has its fair share of other races living with them as well. They are also famous for putting up signs in Jawi language as well regardless of how foreign the name might sound. And they don’t even speak Arabic. They're Austronesian people, of Malay heritage just like most South East Asian are (Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia, aborigines from Taipei, Malays from South Africa and so on). Having said that, it's often very rare to have friends originating from Brunei that even most of my Malaysian friends are amazed I did have friends from Brunei. It’s a fairly vague question; what is the definition of a country? The term island is even wider, being purely geographical there’s bound to be a gazillion islands most people, or most people you’ll ever meet, haven’t heard about. A country is by definition a geographical region with a distinct national identity. The term is, however, also used when talking about sovereign states, but a country does not have to be an independent country. Nations, on the other hand, are not necessarily geographic, but are groups of people with common characteristics, such as ethnicity, language and tradition. Sovereign states may thus be multi-ethnic, composed of several countries and also nations, but where none of those internal borders necessarily overlap or are contained within that state. Lots of states in Africa and the Middle East is a testament to this, due to the arbitrary borders drawn up by the European colonial powers. As for *sovereign* states that are made up of several countries, the UK, the Netherlands, New Zealand and Denmark are the most common to be defined in this way. A country like Spain could also be considered a sovereign state with constituent countries (Catalunya, Galicia, Basque Country, etc.), but its political system doesn’t reflect this in the same way. That being said, it’s appalling to see how many adult people in the modern world that don’t have a clue about it’s geographical and political make-up. Still, I guess you could be excused for not having heard about Niue, Abkhazia or Karakalpakstan.
